concepts.brief_explanation: A systematic process of exploring the natural world that involves making careful observations, asking focused questions, designing and conducting experiments, and using evidence to improve understanding.
chapter_references: Exploring the Investigative World of Science

concepts.brief_explanation: The basic structural, functional, and biological unit of all known living organisms. A cell is the smallest unit of life.
chapter_references: The Invisible Living World: Beyond Our Naked Eye

concepts.brief_explanation: A living organism of microscopic size, such as a bacterium, virus, fungus, protozoan, or alga, that is too small to be seen with the naked eye.
chapter_references: The Invisible Living World: Beyond Our Naked Eye

concepts.brief_explanation: A living being that consists of only a single cell, which carries out all essential life functions. Examples include bacteria and amoeba.
chapter_references: The Invisible Living World: Beyond Our Naked Eye

concepts.brief_explanation: A living being that is composed of many cells, which are typically organized into tissues, organs, and organ systems. Examples include plants and animals.
chapter_references: The Invisible Living World: Beyond Our Naked Eye

concepts.brief_explanation: Unicellular microorganisms that lack a well-defined nucleus. Some are beneficial, aiding in digestion and decomposition, while others can be pathogenic.
chapter_references: The Invisible Living World: Beyond Our Naked Eye

concepts.brief_explanation: A group of microorganisms that can be unicellular (like yeast) or multicellular (like mould). They obtain nutrients by decomposing organic matter.
chapter_references: The Invisible Living World: Beyond Our Naked Eye

concepts.brief_explanation: A diverse group of simple, plant-like aquatic organisms, including unicellular microalgae. They contain chlorophyll and can produce their own food through photosynthesis.
chapter_references: The Invisible Living World: Beyond Our Naked Eye

concepts.brief_explanation: A group of single-celled microorganisms, such as Amoeba and Paramecium. Some are free-living, while others are parasitic and can cause diseases like malaria.
chapter_references: The Invisible Living World: Beyond Our Naked Eye

concepts.brief_explanation: A microscopic, acellular infectious agent that can only replicate inside the living cells of other organisms. Viruses can cause a wide range of diseases.
chapter_references: The Invisible Living World: Beyond Our Naked Eye

concepts.brief_explanation: A metabolic process in which microorganisms like yeast and bacteria convert carbohydrates, such as sugar, into alcohol or acids. This process is used in making foods like bread, curd, and idli.
chapter_references: The Invisible Living World: Beyond Our Naked Eye

concepts.brief_explanation: A state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being, and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity.
A condition that impairs the normal functioning of the body or mind, characterized by specific signs and symptoms.
A disease caused by a pathogen that can be transmitted from one person to another through direct or indirect contact, or via a vector.
A disease that is not caused by a pathogen and cannot be spread from person to person. These are often chronic diseases linked to lifestyle, genetics, or environmental factors.
A disease-causing microorganism, such as a bacterium, virus, fungus, or protozoan.
The natural ability of an organism's body to resist and fight off infection and disease, primarily through the action of the immune system.
A biological preparation that provides active acquired immunity to a particular infectious disease by training the immune system to recognize and destroy the pathogen.
A type of medicine that is effective in killing or inhibiting the growth of bacteria, used to treat bacterial infections.
A phenomenon where bacteria evolve the ability to survive and multiply despite treatment with an antibiotic that was previously effective against them.
The phenomenon where an electric current flowing through a conductor, such as a wire, produces a magnetic field around it. This effect can be observed by the deflection of a nearby magnetic compass.
The region around a magnet or a current-carrying conductor where its magnetic influence can be detected. The presence of a magnetic field can cause a force on other magnets or magnetic materials.
A temporary magnet created by passing an electric current through a coil of wire, often wrapped around an iron core. The magnetic field disappears when the current is turned off.
The phenomenon where a conductor generates heat when an electric current flows through it, due to the resistance of the material to the flow of current.
The opposition to the flow of electric current in a conductor. This property causes electrical energy to be converted into heat.
A common type of electric cell used in portable devices, which uses a moist paste as its electrolyte instead of a liquid.
A type of battery whose chemical reactions can be reversed by applying an external electric current, allowing it to be recharged and reused multiple times.
A push or a pull on an object resulting from its interaction with another object. A force can cause an object to change its state of motion or its shape.
A force that acts on an object by direct contact with it. Examples include muscular force and friction.
A type of contact force produced by the contraction and elongation of muscles in living beings.
A contact force that opposes the relative motion or tendency of such motion between two surfaces in contact.
A force that acts on an object without coming physically in contact with it. Examples include magnetic, electrostatic, and gravitational forces.
A non-contact force exerted by a magnet on another magnet or on a magnetic material.
A non-contact force exerted by an electrically charged object on another charged or uncharged object.
A non-contact, attractive force that exists between any two objects with mass. On Earth, it is the force that pulls objects towards the planet's center.
The measure of the gravitational force acting on an object. It is a force and its SI unit is the newton (N).
The measure of the amount of matter in an object. It is a scalar quantity and its value remains constant regardless of location.
A device used to measure weight or force by observing the extent to which a spring stretches under a load.
An upward force exerted by a fluid (liquid or gas) that opposes the weight of a partially or fully immersed object.
The measure of force applied perpendicular to the surface of an object per unit area over which that force is distributed. Its SI unit is the pascal (Pa).
The pressure exerted by a liquid at any point within it. This pressure increases with the depth (height of the liquid column) and is exerted in all directions.
The pressure exerted by the weight of the atmosphere. Air moves from areas of high atmospheric pressure to areas of low atmospheric pressure, creating wind.
The natural movement of air, especially in the form of a current of air blowing from a particular direction, caused by differences in atmospheric pressure.
A storm characterized by the presence of lightning and its acoustic effect on the Earth's atmosphere, known as thunder. They are typically accompanied by strong winds and heavy rain.
A naturally occurring electrostatic discharge during which two electrically charged regions in the atmosphere or ground temporarily equalize themselves, causing the instantaneous release of energy.
A large-scale, rotating storm system characterized by a low-pressure center, strong winds, and a spiral arrangement of thunderstorms that produce heavy rain. It forms over warm ocean waters.
A local wind that blows from the sea towards the land during the day, caused by differences in air pressure created by the differential heating of land and sea.
A local wind that blows from the land towards the sea during the night, caused by differences in air pressure created by the differential cooling of land and sea.
The principle that all matter is composed of a large number of extremely small particles that are in constant motion. The arrangement and motion of these particles determine the state of matter.
The distinct physical forms in which matter can exist, primarily solid, liquid, and gas. These states are determined by the arrangement, spacing, and attraction between the constituent particles.
A state of matter characterized by a definite shape and volume. In solids, particles are tightly packed in fixed positions and vibrate, with strong interparticle attractions.
A state of matter that has a definite volume but no fixed shape, taking the shape of its container. In liquids, particles are close together but can move past one another.
A state of matter with no fixed shape or volume, expanding to fill any container it occupies. In gases, particles are far apart, move freely and randomly, with negligible interparticle attractions.
The empty spaces that exist between the constituent particles of matter. The amount of interparticle space is minimal in solids, greater in liquids, and largest in gases.
The attractive forces that exist between the constituent particles of matter, holding them together. These forces are strongest in solids, weaker in liquids, and negligible in gases.
The specific temperature at which a solid substance changes its state to become a liquid at atmospheric pressure.
The specific temperature at which a liquid substance changes its state to become a gas (vapor) at atmospheric pressure.
A pure substance consisting of only one type of atom, which cannot be broken down into simpler substances by chemical means. Elements are the fundamental building blocks of matter.
chapter_references: Nature of Matter: Elements, Compounds, and Mixtures

concepts.brief_explanation: A pure substance formed when two or more different elements are chemically combined in a fixed ratio. The properties of a compound are different from those of its constituent elements.
chapter_references: Nature of Matter: Elements, Compounds, and Mixtures

concepts.brief_explanation: A substance made by combining two or more substances (elements or compounds) that are not chemically bonded. The individual components of a mixture retain their own properties.
chapter_references: Nature of Matter: Elements, Compounds, and Mixtures

concepts.brief_explanation: A form of matter that has a constant chemical composition and characteristic properties. Pure substances, such as elements and compounds, cannot be separated into simpler components by physical means.
chapter_references: Nature of Matter: Elements, Compounds, and Mixtures

concepts.brief_explanation: A mixture in which the components are evenly distributed and cannot be distinguished from one another, even with a microscope. It is also known as a solution.
chapter_references: Nature of Matter: Elements, Compounds, and Mixtures
The Amazing World of Solutes, Solvents, and Solutions

concepts.brief_explanation: A mixture in which the components are not evenly distributed and can be visibly distinguished from one another.
chapter_references: Nature of Matter: Elements, Compounds, and Mixtures

concepts.brief_explanation: The substance that is dissolved in a solvent to form a solution. It is typically present in a smaller amount.
chapter_references: The Amazing World of Solutes, Solvents, and Solutions

concepts.brief_explanation: The substance in which a solute dissolves to form a solution. It is typically present in a larger amount.
chapter_references: The Amazing World of Solutes, Solvents, and Solutions

concepts.brief_explanation: A solution in which the maximum amount of solute has been dissolved in a solvent at a given temperature, and no more solute can be dissolved.
chapter_references: The Amazing World of Solutes, Solvents, and Solutions

concepts.brief_explanation: A solution that contains less solute than the maximum amount it can dissolve at a given temperature, meaning more solute can still be dissolved.
chapter_references: The Amazing World of Solutes, Solvents, and Solutions

concepts.brief_explanation: The maximum amount of a solute that can dissolve in a fixed quantity of a solvent at a specific temperature to form a saturated solution.
chapter_references: The Amazing World of Solutes, Solvents, and Solutions

concepts.brief_explanation: A curved mirror whose reflecting surface is a part of a hollow sphere. Spherical mirrors can be concave (curving inwards) or convex (curving outwards).

A spherical mirror with a reflecting surface that curves inwards. It can form images that are enlarged, diminished, or the same size, and can be erect or inverted, depending on the object's distance. It converges parallel light rays.
A spherical mirror with a reflecting surface that curves outwards. It always forms an image that is erect and diminished in size. It diverges parallel light rays.

A set of two principles that govern the reflection of light from any surface. The first law states that the angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection. The second law states that the incident ray, the reflected ray, and the normal at the point of incidence all lie in the same plane.
A piece of transparent material, like glass or plastic, with one or two curved surfaces that refracts light passing through it to form an image.
A lens that is thicker in the middle than at the edges. It converges parallel light rays and can form images that are enlarged, diminished, erect, or inverted depending on the object's distance.
A lens that is thinner in the middle than at the edges. It diverges parallel light rays and always forms an image that is erect and diminished in size.

The changing shapes of the Moon's illuminated portion as seen from Earth, which occur in a cyclical pattern over approximately one month. These phases (e.g., new moon, crescent, full moon) result from the changing relative positions of the Sun, Earth, and Moon.
A system for organizing days, months, and years based on astronomical cycles, such as the Earth's rotation (day), the Moon's phases (month), and the Earth's revolution around the Sun (year).
A calendar system based on the monthly cycles of the Moon's phases. A lunar year typically consists of 12 lunar months.
A calendar system whose dates indicate the season or the apparent position of the Sun relative to the stars. The Gregorian calendar is a solar calendar.
A calendar that combines lunar and solar cycles, where months are based on the Moon's phases but an extra month is periodically added to keep the calendar year synchronized with the seasons.
A human-made object intentionally placed into orbit around a celestial body, such as Earth. They are used for communication, navigation, weather monitoring, and scientific research.
A biological community of interacting organisms (biotic components) and their physical environment (abiotic components).
The natural home or environment of an animal, plant, or other organism that provides the conditions necessary for it to live and grow.
The living or once-living parts of an ecosystem, including plants, animals, and microorganisms.
The non-living chemical and physical parts of an ecosystem, such as sunlight, air, water, soil, and temperature.
A group of individuals of the same species living and interbreeding within a given area.
An interacting group of various species in a common location. It consists of all the different populations of organisms living together in a habitat.
An organism, typically a plant or alga, that produces its own food through photosynthesis. Producers form the base of a food chain.
An organism that obtains energy by feeding on other organisms. Consumers can be herbivores, carnivores, or omnivores.
An organism, such as a bacterium or fungus, that breaks down dead organic material, returning essential nutrients to the ecosystem.
A linear sequence of organisms where nutrients and energy are transferred from one organism to another, showing a 'who eats whom' relationship.
A complex network of interconnected food chains within an ecosystem, showing the multiple feeding relationships among different organisms.
The position an organism occupies in a food chain, such as producer, primary consumer (herbivore), or secondary consumer (carnivore).
The process by which dead organic substances are broken down into simpler organic or inorganic matter by decomposers, recycling nutrients within an ecosystem.
The orbital region around a star where conditions are just right for a planet to have liquid water on its surface, a key requirement for life as we know it.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

concepts.brief_explanation: The process by which certain gases in a planet's atmosphere trap heat from the sun, warming the planet's surface to a temperature above what it would be without this atmosphere.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

concepts.brief_explanation: The layer of gases surrounding the planet Earth that is retained by Earth's gravity. It provides oxygen for respiration, traps heat, and contains the ozone layer which blocks harmful UV radiation.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

concepts.brief_explanation: A region of Earth's stratosphere that absorbs most of the Sun's harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation, acting as a protective shield for life on Earth.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

concepts.brief_explanation: The magnetic field that extends from the Earth's interior out into space, where it meets the solar wind. It acts as a shield, protecting the planet from harmful high-energy particles from space.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

concepts.brief_explanation: The biological process by which new individual organisms are produced from their parents, ensuring the continuity of a species. It can be asexual or sexual.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

concepts.brief_explanation: A type of reproduction involving a single parent that results in offspring that are genetically identical to the parent. Examples include vegetative propagation in plants and budding in Hydra.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

concepts.brief_explanation: A type of reproduction involving two parents that combine their genetic material to produce a new organism that differs from both parents. It involves processes like pollination and fertilization.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

concepts.brief_explanation: A type of asexual reproduction in plants where new plants grow from parts of the parent plant, such as stems, roots, or leaves.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

concepts.brief_explanation: A specialized reproductive cell (e.g., sperm or egg in animals, pollen or ovule in plants) that contains half the genetic material of the parent organism.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

concepts.brief_explanation: The process in sexual reproduction where male and female gametes fuse to form a zygote.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

concepts.brief_explanation: The initial cell formed when two gamete cells are joined by means of sexual reproduction. It contains the complete set of genetic material for a new individual.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

concepts.brief_explanation: Long-term shifts in temperatures and weather patterns, primarily caused by human activities like burning fossil fuels, which release greenhouse gases and lead to global warming.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

concepts.brief_explanation: The long-term heating of Earth's climate system observed since the pre-industrial period due to human activities, primarily fossil fuel burning, which increases heat-trapping greenhouse gas levels in Earth's atmosphere.
chapter_references: Our Home: Earth, a Unique Life-Sustaining Planet

activities.activity_name: Thinking like a scientist about a puri
activities.learning_goal: To understand the process of scientific investigation by formulating questions, identifying variables, and suggesting experimental controls for a simple, everyday phenomenon.

activities.activity_name: Observing magnification with a water-filled flask
activities.learning_goal: To understand the principle of magnification by observing that a round-bottom flask filled with water can make letters on a page appear larger.
To prepare a slide of an onion peel, stain it, and observe the basic structure of a plant cell, including the cell wall and nucleus, under a microscope.
To prepare a slide of human cheek cells, stain them, and observe the basic structure of an animal cell, including the cell membrane, cytoplasm, and nucleus.
To discover the presence of microscopic life by observing a drop of pond or stagnant water under a microscope.
To discover the presence of microscopic life in soil by observing a drop of soil suspension under a microscope.
To understand the role of microorganisms in decomposition by observing how fruit and vegetable peels turn into manure when mixed with soil over time.

activities.activity_name: Observing the action of yeast in dough
activities.learning_goal: To demonstrate that yeast causes dough to rise by comparing a dough made with yeast to one made without it, and understanding that this is due to the production of carbon dioxide gas.
To understand the role of bacteria (Lactobacillus) and temperature in the fermentation process of converting milk into curd.
To identify the causal agents, sites of infection, symptoms, and preventive measures for common communicable diseases.
To identify common lifestyle-related non-communicable diseases, their symptoms, and the lifestyle changes that can help prevent or manage them.

activities.activity_name: Investigating the magnetic effect of current
activities.learning_goal: To observe that an electric current flowing through a wire causes a nearby magnetic compass needle to deflect, demonstrating the magnetic effect of the current.
To construct a simple electromagnet by wrapping an insulated wire around an iron nail and connecting it to a cell, and to observe its ability to attract iron clips.

activities.activity_name: Investigating the properties of an electromagnet
activities.learning_goal: To demonstrate that a current-carrying coil behaves like a magnet, that an iron core strengthens it, and that it has two opposite poles.

activities.activity_name: Observing the heating effect of current
activities.learning_goal: To observe that a nichrome wire becomes warm when an electric current is passed through it for a short duration.
To construct a simple Voltaic cell using lemons, copper wires, and iron nails, and to verify its electricity production by lighting an LED.
To experience that moving an object requires applying a push or a pull, which is defined as a force.
To identify from everyday examples that applying a force can change an object's speed, direction of motion, or shape.
To observe that a moving object slows down and stops due to an opposing force (friction) and that this force depends on the nature of the surfaces in contact.
To demonstrate electrostatic force by rubbing a plastic scale and observing its ability to attract small, uncharged pieces of paper.
To demonstrate that like charges repel by rubbing two balloons with a woollen cloth and observing them move away from each other.

activities.activity_name: Observing objects falling due to gravity
activities.learning_goal: To observe that objects thrown upwards invariably fall back to the ground, indicating the presence of a downward attractive force from the Earth.

activities.activity_name: Measuring weight with a spring balance
activities.learning_goal: To learn how to read and use a spring balance to measure the weight of different objects.
To experience the upward push (buoyant force) exerted by water on an object by pushing an empty plastic bottle into a bucket of water.
To demonstrate that the pressure exerted by a liquid depends on the height of the liquid column, not its weight or volume.
To demonstrate the existence of atmospheric pressure by showing that more effort is needed to lift a plate covered by a larger area of paper.

activities.activity_name: Observing air movement due to pressure difference
activities.learning_goal: To demonstrate that air moves from a region of high pressure to a region of low pressure by connecting an inflated balloon to an uninflated one.

activities.activity_name: Observing the effect of high-speed winds on pressure
activities.learning_goal: To demonstrate that high-speed winds are accompanied by reduced air pressure by blowing air between two suspended balloons and observing them move towards each other.

activities.activity_name: Exploring the particulate nature of chalk
activities.learning_goal: To understand that matter is composed of smaller particles by repeatedly breaking and grinding a piece of chalk into a fine powder.
To infer that matter is made of tiny particles that can occupy interparticle spaces by observing sugar dissolve in water without being visible.
To identify the common properties of solids, such as having a definite shape and volume, by observing and handling various solid objects.
To demonstrate that liquids have a definite volume but take the shape of their container by transferring a fixed volume of water between different shaped vessels.
To demonstrate that gases have no fixed shape or volume and will expand to fill the available space by observing smoke spreading between two connected gas jars.
To show that gases have large interparticle spaces by demonstrating that air in a syringe can be easily compressed.
To visualize that particles in a liquid are in constant motion by observing how potassium permanganate color spreads through water.

activities.activity_name: Observing the presence of carbon dioxide in air
activities.learning_goal: To demonstrate that air is a mixture containing carbon dioxide by showing that lime water turns milky when exposed to air.
To infer that sugar is a compound by heating it and observing its decomposition into carbon (a black residue) and water.

activities.activity_name: Comparing a mixture and a compound of iron and sulfur
activities.learning_goal: To distinguish between a mixture and a compound by comparing the properties of an iron-sulfur mixture with the properties of the iron sulfide compound formed after heating.

activities.activity_name: Investigating how much solute can dissolve
activities.learning_goal: To understand the concept of saturation by observing that a fixed amount of solvent can only dissolve a limited amount of solute at a given temperature.

activities.activity_name: Investigating the effect of temperature on solubility
activities.learning_goal: To demonstrate that the solubility of most solids (like baking soda) in water increases as the temperature of the water increases.

activities.activity_name: Measuring mass with a digital balance
activities.learning_goal: To learn the correct procedure for measuring the mass of a solid object using a digital weighing balance, including the use of the tare function.

activities.activity_name: Measuring volume with a measuring cylinder
activities.learning_goal: To learn how to accurately read and measure a specific volume of a liquid using a measuring cylinder, paying attention to the meniscus.

activities.activity_name: Measuring the volume of an irregular solid
activities.learning_goal: To determine the volume of an irregularly shaped solid object using the water displacement method with a measuring cylinder.
To observe the differences in images formed by the inner (concave) and outer (convex) surfaces of a shiny spoon, introducing the concept of spherical mirrors.

activities.activity_name: Exploring images in concave and convex mirrors
activities.learning_goal: To compare the characteristics (size, orientation) of images formed by concave and convex mirrors as the object's distance changes.
To verify the law of reflection by measuring and comparing the angle of incidence and the angle of reflection for a light ray hitting a plane mirror.

activities.activity_name: Observing convergence and divergence by mirrors
activities.learning_goal: To demonstrate that a concave mirror converges parallel light rays while a convex mirror diverges them.

activities.activity_name: Exploring lenses with a water drop
activities.learning_goal: To understand that a curved transparent surface acts as a lens by observing the magnification of text through a water drop.
To compare the characteristics of images formed by convex and concave lenses at varying distances.

activities.activity_name: Observing convergence and divergence by lenses
activities.learning_goal: To demonstrate that a convex lens converges parallel light rays while a concave lens diverges them.

activities.activity_name: Documenting the phases of the Moon
activities.learning_goal: To observe, record, and analyze the changing appearance and position of the Moon over a month to understand its phases.

activities.activity_name: Modeling the phases of the Moon
activities.learning_goal: To simulate how the phases of the Moon occur by observing the illuminated portion of a ball (Moon) as it revolves around one's head (Earth) under a light source (Sun).
To measure the length of a solar day by identifying the time when a vertical stick's shadow is shortest on consecutive days.
To practice observing the night sky to identify and distinguish artificial satellites from other celestial objects.
To identify and list the living (biotic) and non-living (abiotic) components of two different local habitats.
To understand the concept of a population by counting the number of individuals of specific organisms within a defined area.
To classify different organisms as producers, herbivores, carnivores, or omnivores based on their feeding habits.

activities.activity_name: Linking organisms in a food chain
activities.learning_goal: To construct a food chain by drawing arrows to show the flow of energy ('who eats whom') among a given set of organisms in an ecosystem.

activities.activity_name: Tracing links in a food web
activities.learning_goal: To understand the interconnectedness of feeding relationships in an ecosystem by adding missing links to a diagram of a food web.
To observe asexual reproduction in plants by planting different plant parts (stem, tuber, rhizome) and watching them grow into new plants.
